Major American airlines were raising their bag charges as a way to protect their profits from rising fuel and labor costs.

"What the airlines are facing right now is that their costs are rising at about twice the rate of their incomes," said Samuel Engel, the senior vice president at the consulting group ICF. As a result, he said, airlines are looking for ways to increase profits.

Mr. Engel said, "The baggage fee is an easy target. And the nice thing about the baggage fee is, it's a way to make your least loyal customer pay for the increase. Those people who represent the airlines' most valuable income will not see this increase."

Mr. Engel also noted that bag fees were a good way to get passengers to pay more without raising fares. Lower fares get more attention on flight search engines, and bag fees are not a factor in the price that is displayed.

In a statement, United Airlines insisted that higher fees were a way to maintain its current level of service. The airline said, "These changes allow us to continue investing in the overall customer experience in today's marketplace."
